Award.AbstractNarration:
Proof assistants can express any precise computing task in formal systems of logic. They specify exactly how hardware and software are required to operate and use the specifications to guide implementations. Computer scientists using these tools have achieved over the past two decades the highest levels of correctness known. Proof assistants draw on advanced mathematics; they have been used to check the validity of several deep mathematical results and discover new ones. In this process, leading mathematicians contributed powerful new concepts into the formal logics. Fields Medalist Vladimir Voevodsky proposed a new mathematical principle, called Univalence. It has been an open question whether this principle has computational interpretations. That question was affirmatively answered recently by the PI and his collaborators. The intellectual merits of this project consist in formal verification of the correctness of these interpretations using a proof assistant. The project's broader significance and importance are to enhance their impact on many critical applications of computing systems in science, engineering, and industry and to explore their use in teaching Euclidean geometry to high school students.

This research project on Constructive Univalent Foundations significantly raises the levels of abstraction that proof assistants can support, and increases the range of problems they help solve. Preliminary results by the PI and his team provide strong evidence that Univalent Foundations and the computational type theory using it will significantly improve the capabilities of proof assistants and thus the reliability and capabilities of hardware and software on which modern computing systems depend, from the desktop to the cloud. The project formally verifies the correctness of the computational interpretations of Univalence in the proof assistant Nuprl that has been developed by the PI and his collaborators over the last three decades.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The EAGER: Constructive Univalent Foundations funding enabled the Cornell team to help Fields Medalist Vladimir Voevodsky verify the correctness of his key axiom for univalent foundations  He visited the Cornell CS department and worked with us intensely for a week to confirm this important axiom.  We verified the axiom and published the result.. This work has allowed us to build on the result and publish related articles that are available on the web page of the PRL research group. Adding the url to a POR sometimes causes this reporting system to reject the submission or even crash.  On previous attempts to submit this POR the system has crashed. So we suggest looking up the name of our proof assistant, Nuprl, or logging into the Cornell web cite for this information using Nuprl in the title.

Subsequently we have applied these results to make advances in Homotopy Type Theory and related areas.  This includes providing a constructive proof of  Brouwer's famous fixed point theorem, the approximate fixed point version,  As far as we know this is he only formally synthesized and verified version of this well known result, It is available on the web page mentioned.

We have also invested considerable resourses to implement elements of Brouwer's intuitionistic mathematics, including the key Continuity Theorem. This is evidence that NSF made an investment which has continued to produce results for many years and has led us to broaden our research agenda. That investment will continue to pay off for many more years as we advance this important area.  Our recent work on this topic has shown interesting connections to physics and our formal understanding of light waves.  We have started to lecture on these results.  We think that this project is an excellent example of the role of NSF in advancing topics at the intersection of computer science and mathematics.

R. L. Constable for the Cornell University Nuprl group in Computer Science.
